Lich bane gives more ap and better ap scaling, overall it will still be better.

Lichbane gives 30 more AP and a 20% higher ratio, but it's single target. Rune is 30% ratio with a 100% base AD ratio that turns the ENTIRE attack, that means an Ez's Q and Fizz's Q, into Magic Damage rather than dealing physical. It also synergizes well with Diana's kit, making her AoE-loving kit do lots more AoE while also making her AA do lots of damage.

I'll even compare it for you. Say you have 500 AP with this item and 530 with the Lichbane.

500 AP on this item makes your next AA do around 100 base damage which is now magic, another 100 because of its ratio, and 30% of your AP, so that's 100+100+150, so 350. Lichbane does 75% of your base AD and 50% of your AP, so that's 100 base PHYSICAL, 75 Magic, and 265 magic, totaling 340 magic and 100 physical. That's just for a standard AA though. There's about a 90 damage difference prior to resistances. Most have about 80ish MR and about 100 Armor, but say you have a void, so you ignore 40% of their MR.

We're at 48 MR and 100 armor. 100 armor is 50% reduction. Formula is MR/(MR+100). You likely have another 23 MPen. 8 from runes, 15 from boots. So that's 25 MR left. 25 MR is 20% reduction. That means the Rune will do about 280. The Lich would do 50 physical and 272 magical. That means there's about a 42 damage difference on your average carry. Literally 42. That's almost negligible. lol. 

Say we want to use a tank though! That's about 200 armor and 100 MR, pretty standard stuff. 200 Armor is about 67% reduction. 100 MR is 50%, however we ignore 40% of it and another 23, bringing us down to 37. (100-40% is 60, minus 23 is 37). 37 MR is about 27% reduction. So Rune does 255.5 damage. Lich does 33 physical and 248.2 damage. That means the difference is 25.7 damage.

Needless to say, the more armor there is on a target, including if they grab a Zhonya's, the less the difference between a Lich and a Rune becomes because of the initial damage being converted into magical.

All this math is done with the upgraded Runeglaive that has a 100% base AD ratio and 50 AP, up from 40.

Your math is completely off.

It doesn't _add a base damage_, it works off of the champions "base physical attack + 30% of your AP".

The only items that add a base amount of damage are Nashor's Tooth (which has a scaling) and Wits End.

Nashor's Tooth: http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Nashor%27s_Tooth
Wits End: http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Wits_End

lets take your Example but we'll use a level 18 Diana {{champion:131}} JUST to compare:

Diana: http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Diana
Runeglaive: http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Runeglaive
Lich Bane: http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Lichbane

level 18 Diana with 104 base AD and 500 AP. 


With Runeglaive: 

100% of physical base damage of 104 = 104.
30% of 500 AP = 150

[104 physical base +  150 Magic damage] = 254 Magic damage on next autoattack

With Lich Bane: 

75% of physical base damage of 104 = 78
50% of 500 AP = 250 Magic damage

[78 physical base + 250 magic damage] = 328 magic damage on next autoattack

With that, thats a difference of _74 damage_.

While Runeglaive is AoE, Lich Bane scales so much **harder** if you're stacking more AP to make use it. Whats the ball park of high end amounts of AP?

600?

800?

Not sure if I misunderstand you, but are you implying that only the "bonus" magic damage mentioned in the tooltips of Spellblade unique passive of both items will be dealt as the damage when you auto attack after using an ability (or when you use an ability that applies on-hit effects)?

Because that's obviously not what the tooltips are telling us. If you read carefully:
> Lich Bane: After using an ability, your next basic attack deals 75% base AD (+ 50% AP) **BONUS** magic damage. 1.5 second cooldown.

>Runeglaive: After using an ability, your next basic attack is converted to deal magic damage **PLUS** 75% base AD (+30% AP) **BONUS** damage in an area around the target. Applies spell effects. (1.5 second cooldown).

Let's use Ezreal as an example and illustration shall we?

Level 18 Ezreal has 101 base Attack Damage. Let's say he has 650 Ability Power, and he does not build any items/runes/masteries  that gives him more **base Attack Damage**/**bonus Attack Damage**, so his total Attack Damage remains 101.

With Runeglaive:

His Q's component = 115 + 101 x 110% + 650 x 40% = 486.1

Plus

Spellblade passive bonus Magic Damage = 101 x 75% + 650 x 30% = 270.75

So the total Magic Damage he deals upon using Q = 486.1 + 210.75 = 786.85

Not to mention since Runeglaive's unique passive activates spell effects, Luden's Echo's unique passive will be proced too, assuming he has Luden's Echo and Luden's Echo is at full charge, but let's not talk about the numbers on Luden's Echo's unique passive, for simplicity's sake. Also with Runeglaive, Ezreal's Q is completely converted into magic damage which synergizes well with any magic penetration runes/masteries/items (if any) you have applied on Ezreal. It works extremely well with Abyssal Sceptor (Not a very nice item on Ezreal since almost all of his abilities revolves around ranged pokes) /Void Staff.

With Lich Bane:

his Q component = 486.1

Plus

Spellblade passive bonus Magic Damage = 101 x 75% + 650 x 50% = 400.75

Total = 486.1 (Physical Damage from Ezreal's Q) + 400.75 (Magic Damage component from Spellblade passive) = 886.85

Ezreal's Q is Physical Damage component, so it doesn't benefit from magic penetration. Granted that it deals more damage (130 more damage) in total, but half of the damage is Physical Damage (which doesn't do much for AP Ezreal), and the other half is Magic Damage. Moreover, Ezreal's Q does not proc Luden's Echo's unique passive since it isn't treated as a spell. It only procs on-hit effects like Spellblade.

Conclusion (TL;DR): Both builds have their advantages and disadvantages. Just because Runeglaive doesn't deal as much damage in total does not mean it's a bad idea to build it on AP Ezreal.

Sorry again for misunderstandings if I misunderstand your post. But the the above conclusion remains.

**EDIT**: I totally forgot to mention that most AP Runeglaive Ezreal players build Skirmisher's Sabre, thus making their smite Challenging Smite. This is important because it makes every basic attack and his Qs proc extra true damage on the Smited enemy champions. I don't need to go through the numbers right?
See, this guy understands. When you auto attack, you do hit with your physical damage AA with the other bits as BONUS. Runeglaive turns the ENTIRE attack, including the initial AA, into magic.

I see a lot of benefit for AP ezreal and AP gangplank, who have a physical ability that counts as a basic attack youd like to turn into magic damage. But how does it help AP junglers?

Runeglave turns 75% of your AD + 30% of your AP into magic damage. Lich bane adds 75% of your AD + 50% of your AP on top of your basic autoattack damage. For most AP junglers, Lich bane is still better.

The bigger problem is that rushing either item is a bad idea, which is fine for Lich Bane users - they just finish it later.  Runeglaive doesn't have that choice, as the enchantment is meant to catch the jungler back up from the gold spent on PvE stats.

Yeah, Runeglaive is great on specifically, and almost entirely, on Diana, but that is pretty much who uses it the most, and can benefit from it the most outside of Eve, compared to the old AP item. The other actual junglers that are ap don't really benefit from it as well as they did the old version, which is what bothers people.

Sure, it is cute and all that Ezreal can use it, but that sort of isn't the point of the item, and if anything is going to get it nerfed if people start using it on him, hence why Cinderhulk got nerfed most recent with all the top laners taking it.

Same reason the old (pre-the new summoner's rift jungle items) jungle item got nerfed with Ez using it too much (not just Ez but he was the main offender).


If part of your argument is, non-junglers can use it and do good, that is a terrible argument, and only further points out why it isn't a good item, because it is not only worse on previous AP junglers, it actually lowers the amount of viable AP junglers (which one of the Rioters flat out said that exact thing on the most recent patch rundown).

Pretty sure an item that makes LESS champions viable in the jungler and causes MORE non-junglers to use it in lane...is bad.

Thing is.... how many remotely popular AP Junglers (talking about non-tanks even if a few tanks scale well with AP) are there?  {{champion:76}} {{champion:131}} {{champion:9}} {{champion:245}} {{champion:60}} {{champion:28}} These champions mostly come to mind.  Two of them don't do well with Runeglaive (Fiddle can rush Zhonyas and most Elise's opt for Cinderhulk because of her awful damage scaling anyway).  Then there's some other picks that exist but aren't really played often at all like {{champion:84}} {{champion:30}} {{champion:38}}.  Once again, only one of these champions can't make great use of Runeglaive.  Then there's AP {{champion:35}} , but I imagine he'd do fine with Runeglaive.  Essentially there are very few junglers that did not benefit from the switch to Runeglaive, and those champions have ways to circumvent it anyway.

I think the point is that each of the champs that benefit from glaive benefit far more from lich bane. Also they did t have to remove the old magus which benefits plenty of ap jungler, both could exist.

> [{quoted}](name=Malix Farwin,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=iiYbEZF1,comment-id=00000001,timestamp=2015-07-01T10:22:51.250+0000)
>
> Lich bane gives more ap and better ap scaling, overall it will still be better.

Runeglaive is AoE and provides cleaning.

Still on most junglers wouldnt an Iceborne be better in that it deals similar aoe damage and brings damage mitigation, mana, and an aoe slow to the table? When I think about playing maoki which would be better, glaive and sunfire or cinderhulk and iceborn?

I don't understand why people always bring up Iceborne. It doesn't deal any where near as much damage as a Runeglaive since Runeglaive has an AP ratio instead of just a base AD ratio AND it does physical damage, so it's mitigated by base armors far more than a Runeglaive since Rune does pure magic, even going as far as to change THE ENTIRE ATTACK into magic, which is why AP Ez is loving it. That 200ish base phys damage because MAGICAL and does AOE. That also applies to Fizz's Q, turning it into pure magic, and of course the trolly build of AP GP also gets his Q completely magic damage. 

I don't understand how people are failing to realize just how powerful this item is. o.o It's scary good and synergizes with all the AP junglers except for Fiddle.

As for Mao, you always get Cinder. You wouldn't ever get the AP item. 0.o A Mao with Cinder is way better than Magus and a Runeglaive isn't all that great for him. Better off with as tanky items as it gets. This new item is for Jungle CARRIES like Diana and Fizz and even Ekko.

People are comparing it to iceborn, because iceborn offers similar damage output when at low AP. Offers not that much less AP, twice as much mana. An AoE slow. And a nice bit of armor.

Runeglaive is kind of awkward when compared to it because it gives no defensive stats, as lackluster offensive stats, and doesn't offer the slow.

The only things it offers which iceborn doesn't, is mana regen and AP scaling.

And the AP scaling can't measure up to lichbane.

---

I think it's looking really good with the changes on the PBE really. upping the base AD% to 100% helps a bit with the early game.

I still feel like 60 AP is a minimum of what it should have, just to compete with warrior. But even so it's looking a lot better.

30 AP is negligible really, especially if you make your 2nd item a big AP item like a Rabadon's, Zhonya's, or Luden's. You only lose out on 30 AP, but you get a bigger base damage, plus your ENTIRE attack is turned into magic, which means the actual AA you used to get off the bonus damage is turned into magic. 

Compared to an Iceborne that only gives 125% of your base AD as AoE when this gives 100% plus 30% of your AP? If you're at max, you prolly have 100 AD, so to get it to equal about 25 damage with just the AP ratio to make it do more would be about 84ish AP. 30% of 84 is 25.2, which you usually have when you finish this item if you have the usual rune set up for AP carries. Damage-wise, Iceborne won't ever compare and it's not meant to. It's meant to be a slow and tankiness, not damage output.

As I said. I think the buffs on the PBE makes it look more appealing as it's own item.

In the phase where you only have one full item it's very much comparable to iceborn.

My initial criticism of the item was that champions who want lichbane gets a weaker lichbane with half the AP and no movespeed. While champions who want Iceborn get none of the tankiness and utility(slow) and are now more dependent on stacking AP.

Buffing the base AD ratio helps seperating it from both lichbane and iceborn. (since it's now a lot easier to make it outdo iceborn in damage, and the improved base ratio makes makes it stand out more from lichbane in the early game before you stack a lot of AP.

I still think it needs 10 more AP (or 5% more CDR, because I think the game could use more 5/15% CDR items) than what is on the PBE to be fully competitive as a source of AP.

See, that's the thing. Currently on the PBE, it sits as a wonderful item with a lot of potential and does incredibly. If they buff it anymore than what it is, then why wouldn't people just take smite mid for it like Diana? She has to jump into an enemy team anyways, so why not snag up the smite? Same could really go for Akali who scales incredibly well with a Sheen. Sheen and the smite at level 6 would mean she'd be able to all in them instantly just like a Diana could because extra damage off Challenging smite, reduced damage from their opponent who's only option to face these monsters is to burst them unless they've got an escape. Same could be said about Fizz since his Q does PHYSICAL damage with an AP ratio. This turns his Q into magical and considering he has to AA, the challenging smite works too good with his kit. He doesn't usually need an offensive summoner to kill some one at level 6, he only needs his Lichbane and to land his R. This gives him a cheaper Lichbane and a much shorter CD ignite with more base damage, skyrocketing his early game and snowballing him ungodly well.

Do we REALLY want to see a Fizz get to 6 with a Runeglaive and be raping everything like he used to? D:

What you don't get is that Cinderhulk and Sunfire Cape are two _completely_ different items. Lich Bane offers double the ability power, more mana, and a better Spellblade considering that most of the AP junglers that use it are assassins. Just imagine is Sunfire Cape offered a bonus 35% HP and more health instead of the usual 25% that Cinderhulk gives, and the percentages don't stack. That basically sums up Runeglaive compared to the other items with the same passive. It is mediocre in almost every way, but since we are a jungler we are pretty much force to build a jungle item, even if it is the worst alternative. That's how AP junglers feel right now. There are way better spellblades than Runeglaive.

You must be new here? A lot of balance changes makes no sense. I still want a new balance Team. Look at the Elise changes, Shyvana changes, Magus removed, the sated devourer(so op cant believe it will hit live) and now the runeglaive.

Some people in this thread don't get that one of the main reasons it is amazing on ez is that it turns his Q into MAGIC DAMAGE. Which means ludens now procs with it and magic pen now works with his Q. This took out a huge weakness in his kit. Also he can just run to raptors and get back a good chunk of mana once and a while. If he falls behind early though and can't get a fast runeglaive he is really meh.

Some people in this thread don't get the fact that a jungle item being great on not a jungler is what makes it a bad item. If they want to make an item that does this for mages in general, then sure, great item, but this is a jungle item, and lane Ez shouldn't be taking it at all. The fact that it works better on Ez than pretty much every other AP jungler outside of 1, is a pretty big downside for a JUNGLE item.
Cinderhulk isn't a bad item because it's good on non-junglers.  Likewise, if Runeglaive is decent outside of the jungle, that's not its problem.  The problem is that it's not good in the jungle.

I never said cinderhulk was bad, nor did I say it was bad that non-junglers played it, because given how pro top laners played, with thier early taking camps and so on and so forth, it made sense, and it worked. 

Cinderhulk in general was just sort of strong, but it wasn't problematic. The problem, and what my point was, having an item that is better on someone out of the jungle, compared to a lot of junglers, is bad. 

Fiddle worked fine with Magus, but he rarely auto attacks in the jungle, because you rarely, if ever aren't draining or some such to have time to auto, so it mostly just nerfed him with less ap.

The problem I have with Ez using it specifically, is because we have already seen a case where a good jungle item was picked up on Ez, then nerfed pretty roughly (the old map and jungle items) and then it was bad on everyone.

When items are picked up on people Riot doesn't want them picked up on, it rarely, if ever, ends good.

We can go all the way back to Heart of Gold, which was mainly meant to be a way for junglers to get passive gold and some health (there weren't as many easy ways for health then in comparison, outside of a few cases). Just about every laner started taking Heart of Gold, what happened? Riot straight up deleted it from the game so no one could use it, which hurt jungler gold income for a bit.

An jungle item being good, not on a jungler, but a laner, is bad in my opinion. Riot still, somehow, hasn't learn how to balance an item to be attractive to junglers and not laners, and it ends up the items are attractive for laners and not junglers.

I don't get how they still haven't figured it out for as many times as it has happened, especially with Ezreal.

Well, this time the interactions are a bit screwy and I wouldn't be surprised if they get cleaned up.  Heart of Gold was obvious - you can get the same gp10 the support gets and build your favorite stat while doing so to snowball your lane.  Runeglaive's conversion of next on-hit applying spell to entirely magic damage is a bit of a surprise, but converting a skill that normally doesn't read as a spell to one that does simply because it changes damage type:  that's ridiculous.  If Ez's Q works with on-hits in order to apply runeglaive in the first place, then it shouldn't work with Luden's - it needs to be one or the other.

In any case, I still think the bigger problem is that runeglaive sucks in the jungle.  Whether people can use it outside of the jungle seems to come into play after that.

And I just confirmed on a test run in a custom game.

Runeglaive DOES convert all damage from physical on-hit abilities into all magic damage.

I then proceeded to test why, so I grabbed a Luden's echo.

Each Ezreal Q did proc luden's when fully charged.

I removed Luden's and then added Will of the ancients.

Got a tower to bring me down to half HP and then attacked the scuttler crab. Turns out it spell vamps off of the Q with Runeglaive.

Then I grabbed liandry's torment...

...Found out it works with Ezreal Q as well with Runeglaive.

I did the same thing with a lichbane to make sure it wasn't an error in misjudging what Ezreal Q does (for redundancy).

Turns out Runeglaive converts that autoattack on-hit ability (Ezreal Q) **_into a spell effect._** and Lich bane does not do that which is still treated as an actual on-hit modifier.

My bets are the coding was done wrong and is actually a bug which translate to, 
_**Not intended.**_
